revisions.rev:
{{Infobox person | name = Harriet Walter | image = Harriet Walter - Actress.jpg | caption = Harriet Walter discusses the role of women in Shakespeare plays as part of the RSC's "Stand up for Shakespeare" programme in January 2009 | imagesize = 250px | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1950|9|24|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[London]], [[England]], [[United Kingdom]] | birthname = Harriet Mary Walter | occupation = [[Actress]] | yearsactive = 1974âpresent | spouse = Guy Schuessler
(m.2011-present) }} '''Dame Harriet Mary Walter''', [[Order of the British Empire|DBE]] (born 24 September 1950) is a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[actress]]. ==Personal life== She is the niece of renowned British actor [[Christopher Lee|Sir Christopher Lee]],{{Cite news|last=Fox|first=Chloe|author-link=|last2=|first2=|author2-link=|title=The world of Harriet Walter, actress|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|pages=|year=|date=2007-02-03|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/arts/main.jhtml?xml=/arts/2007/02/03/smworld03.xml|postscript={{inconsistent citations}} }} as the daughter of his elder sister Xandra Lee. On her father's side she is a great-great-great-granddaughter of [[John Walter (publisher)|John Walter]], founder of [[The Times]]http://www.inpublishing.co.uk/news/articles/stationers_celebrate_times_links.aspxShe was educated at the [[Cranbourne Chase School]]. After training at the [[London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art]], she gained early experience with the [[Joint Stock Theatre Company]], [[Paines Plough]] touring, and the [[Duke's Playhouse]], [[Lancaster, Lancashire|Lancaster]].{{cite book|title=[[Who's Who]]|year=1995|publisher=[[A & C Black]]|location=Oxford, England|chapter=Walter, Harriet Mary}} Her partner, until his death in 2004, was actor [[Peter Blythe]].{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/2004/aug/06/guardianobituaries.artsobituaries|title=Obituary: Peter Blythe|last=Shorter|first=Eric|date=6 August 2004|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=26 November 2010}} On 21 May 2011 she married Guy Schuessler, an American actor (stage name Guy Paul)[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/8508200/Harriet-Walter-Why-I-am-getting-married-at-60.html Why I am getting married at 60]. ==Career== She has worked many times throughout her career with the [[Royal Shakespeare Company]], in productions including ''[[Nicholas Nickleby (play)|Nicholas Nickleby]]'' (1980), ''[[A Midsummer Night's Dream]]'' (1981), ''[[All's Well That Ends Well]]'' (1981), ''[[The Castle (novel)|The Castle]]'' (1985), ''[[Three Sisters (play)|Three Sisters]]'' (1988), ''[[The Duchess of Malfi]]'' (1989), ''[[Macbeth]]'' (1999), and ''[[Much Ado about Nothing]]'' (2002). She was made an associate artist of the [[Royal Shakespeare Company]] in 1987. Other theatre work includes ''Three Birds Alighting on a Field'' (1991), ''[[Arcadia (play)|Arcadia]]'' (1993), ''[[Hedda Gabler]]'' (1996), ''[[Ivanov (play)|Ivanov]]'' (1997), and ''Mary Stuart'' (2005). Her films include ''[[Sense and Sensibility (film)|Sense and Sensibility]]'' (1995), ''[[Bedrooms and Hallways]]'' (1998), ''[[Eugene Onegin#Film|Onegin]]'' (1999), ''[[Villa des Roses]]'' (2002), and ''[[Bright Young Things]]'' (2003). ==Honours== She was appointed [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] (CBE) in the 2000 New Year Honours and [[Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] (DBE) in the 2011 New Year Honours for services to drama.{{London Gazette |issue=59647 |date=31 December 2010 |startpage=6 |supp=yes }} Her performance in ''[[Mary Stuart (play)|Mary Stuart]]'' at the [[Donmar Warehouse]] transferred to Broadway, where it was nominated for numerous [[Tony Award]]s, including Best Actress nods for her and her co-star [[Janet McTeer]].{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/stage/2009/may/05/billy-elliot-tony-awards-broadway|title=Billy Elliot musical dominates Broadway's Tony award shortlist|date=5 May 2009|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=26 November 2010}} ==Stage â notable performances== *1981/2, Royal Shakespeare Company, Helena in ''[[All's Well That Ends Well]]'' *1987/8, Royal Shakespeare Company, [[Imogen (Shakespeare)|Imogen]] in ''[[Cymbeline]]'' *1987/8, Royal Shakespeare Company, Viola in ''[[Twelfth Night]]'' ([[Olivier Award]], "Actress of the Year in a Revival", for this production, ''[[A Question of Geography]]'' and ''[[Three Sisters (play)|Three Sisters]]'', below){{cite web|url=http://www.officiallondontheatre.co.uk/olivier_awards/view/item98523/Olivier-Winners-1988/|title=Olivier Winners 1988|date=24 April 2008|publisher=The Official London Theatre Guide|accessdate=28 November 2010}} *1987/8, Royal Shakespeare Company, Dacha in ''A Question of Geography'' *1988, Royal Shakespeare Company, Masha in [[Chekhov]]'s''[[Three Sisters (play)|Three Sisters]]'' *1989/90, Royal Shakespeare Company, Duchess in [[John Webster]]'s ''[[The Duchess of Malfi]]'' *1991, Royal Court Theatre, and Broadway transfer, Biddy in [[Timberlake Wertenbaker]]'s "[[Three Birds Alighting on a Field]]" *1993, Royal National Theatre, Lady Croom in ''[[Arcadia (play)|Arcadia]]'' by [[Tom Stoppard]] *1999 Royal Shakespeare Company, Lady Macbeth in ''[[Macbeth]]'' *2002 Royal National Theatre Paige in ''[[Dinner (play)|Dinner]]'' by Moira Buffini, co-starring [[Nicholas Farrell]] and [[Catherine McCormack]]. *2005, [[Donmar Warehouse]] and [[West End theatre|West End]], ''[[Maria Stuart (play)|Mary Stuart]]'' by [[Schiller]] ("Best Actress" in [[Evening Standard Theatre Awards]]) *2006, Royal Shakespeare Company, ''[[Antony and Cleopatra]]'' *2009, ''Mary Stuart'', Broadway transfer *2010, Royal National Theatre â ''[[Women Beware Women]]'' ==Television== ===Documentary=== Larina *''[[Villa des Roses]]'' (2002) â Olive *''[[Bright Young Things]]'' (2003) â Lady Maitland *''[[Chromophobia (film)|Chromophobia]]'' (2005) â Penelope Aylesbury *''[[Babel (film)|Babel]]'' (2006) â Lilly *''[[Atonement (film)|Atonement]]'' (2007) â Emily Tallis *''[[Cheri (film)|Cheri]]'' (2009) â La Loupiote *''[[The Young Victoria]]'' (2009) â [[Adelaide of Saxe-Meiningen|Queen Adelaide]] *''[[Morris: A Life with Bells On]]'' (2009) â Professor Compton Chamberlayne ==Radio== *''[[Jeremy Hardy Speaks to the Nation]]'' *''[[Ned Chaillet#Scenes of Seduction|Scenes of Seduction]]'', radio play written by [[Timberlake Wertenbaker]] and directed by [[Ned Chaillet]], broadcast on [[BBC Radio 4]] 7 Mar 2005 â Catherine.[http://bufvc.ac.uk/shakespeare/index.php/title/AV68694 British Universities Film & Video Council â Scenes of Seduction] *''[[Patrick Barlow|Desmond Olivier Dingle]]'' (as herself), broadcast on BBC7 on 28 February 2007, episode 2 of 6, duration 30 minutes *''[[The Arts and How they was done (Radio Show)]]'' (as herself), broadcast on BBC Radio 4 between 4 April and 9 May 2007, episodes 1 and 6 out of 6, duration 30 minuteses *[[I, Claudius (radio adaptation)|I, Claudius]], broadcast on BBC Radio 4 December 2010 â Livia, wife of Augustus. * Guest in [[Desert Island Discs]] on BBC Radio 4 on 26 June 2011. ==Books== *''Macbeth (Actors on Shakespeare)'' (2002).
